results.notes:
Fruiting exclusively beneath mature Douglas firs.
Cap: Canary yellow, very large(16cm across in largest specimen), striated margins. Single, large volval remnant(not warted). Gills: cream colored(not staining).
Stipe: Hollow with cottony, gelatinous interior pith. Images added of cross section.
Not bulbous, but tapered with a saccate volva at base(see added images of cross sections).
Odor: not distinct when fresh. Slightly fishy odor when dehydrating.
Flavor: not distinct.
Spore printing on glass slide for microscopy(images to be added).
Collected both specimens and dehydrated for herbarium collection/voucher.
Microscopy: Spores=broadly ellipsoid.
Mailed labeled collection sample to RET on 5/13/19 for his herbarium. Remaining collection labeled and in home herbarium.

P.P.S If my email is not available on here let me know and I will put it as a comment somewhere. I don’t really anticipate any malicious activity coming from a mushroom foraging site.

results.notes: Fruiting on decaying twig (likely hardwood). Strikers consists of about 4-7 ascomata, erumpent; each ascomata somewhat spherical/ovoid, entostroma with whitish colors, ascomata ~0.25-0.75 mm broad. Ascospores allantoid to somewhat cylindrical, sausage shaped and slightly ornamented/verrucose, pale brownish, ~ 8-11 × 2-2.5 μm; Asci clavate to somewhat (infrequently) mucronate, portion with spores ~ 30-60 × 5-7 μm; paraphyses slender, hyaline and about 1-2 μm at the apices.

results.notes:
On white calcareous shale in coastal scrub habitat.

Thallus scant, consisting of discontinuous rosettes of brown knobby-bullate areoles, minutely marginally lobed (flabellate), with one to several apothecia. Apothecia lecanorine, with a thick, persistent, flush to barely raised thalline margin concolorous with thallus. Disk dark reddish brown, epruinose, plane. Epihymenium light orange, with scattered large POL+ granules. Hymenium hyaline, 125µm tall including epihymenium, K/I+Blue. Hypothecium hyaline. Exciple filled with blue-green algae, which extends thickly across base of apothecium. Cortex dark red-brown with few coarse POL+ orange granules. Medullary tissue below hypothecium and asci POL+ diffuse white. All POL+ granules insoluble in KOH. Asci bacidia-type, clavate, about 110µm tall, with 8 spores, with K/I+blue tholus. Paraphyses thin, weakly branching. All parts strongly coherent even in K. Cortex and algae and epihymenium K+intensifying reddish brown.

Spores submuriform, hyaline, generally pointed on one end. 22-23 × 11-12µm.

results.notes:
Growing from soil among woody debris under a Maclura pomifera in a floodplain. Pseudorrhiza present in the center of the cluster. Young basidiocarps with white veils. Mature basidiocarps lacking annuli. Appendiculate veil remnants on young caps. Pileipellis composed of hyaline, rounded elements. Pleurocystidia rare or absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline, thin-walled, fusoid-ventricose and flexuous. Cheilocystidia meaurements: (27.8) 32.5 – 68.3 (81.1) × (6.6) 7.1 – 9.5 (12.4) µm, Q = (3.9) 4.4 – 7.7 (9.3); N = 30, Me = 49.7 × 8.4 µm; Qe = 5.9. Spores brown and remaining dark brown in 1M KOH. Spore measurements: (6.6) 7 – 8.1 (8.9) × (3) 3.5 – 4.3 (4.7) µm, Q = (1.6) 1.8 – 2.2 (2.5); N = 30, Me = 7.5 × 3.8 µm; Qe = 2

results.notes:
It grows on granitic blocks in semi shadow of pine-tree forest.
Area of colonies is up to 1m2. They are uneven and with bumps.
It has specific shape of areoles with a scar.
NaClO test is usually pink less 1min, then it turns into dirty orange, greenish-yellow up to yellowish-green. Apothecia are irregular coloured but not pure orange as Rh. subdescrepans and Rh. chrysoleuca.
When Rh. subdescrepans grows above Rh. opiniconensis C tests are different.

notes_fields.Habitat: beside parking lot and dumpster amidst mixed hardwood-conifer forest (eastern white pine, oak, maple, poplar, hickory, ash, beech, birch, witch hazel, rhododendron)
notes_fields.Collector(s): D. Newman, A. Pope, J. Ford, M. Brady, R. Rader, N. Baudoin, D. Appelquist, B. Glaser & O. Terran
notes_fields.Comments: This is the single most abundant fruiting of an entomopathogen I have ever seen. All infected flies were found in the immediate vicinity of a dumpster at the corner of the parking lot, which was reported to be swarming with flies about a week prior due to uncollected garbage. Hosts were primarily upside down and affixed to bundles of pine needles, which they gripped with their legs, holding them in a tight bunch. Many specimens saved. Further analyses forthcoming.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1191/2019_DSC5058

Habitat: Sub-Mediterranean macchia; calcareous, skeletal ground, slightly inclined hill slope, west aspect; dry, sunny place; average precipitations ~ 1.000 mm/year, average temperature 13-14 deg C, elevations 65 m (215 feet), Sub-Mediterranean phytogeographical region.

Substratum: small (diameter of less than 8 mm), dead but also alive twigs of Phillyrea latifolia and less frequent of young, bushy Fraxinus ornus branches.

Place: West island Krk, west-southwest of village Brzac, along the trail to the sea shore, Kvarner archipelago, Rijeka region, Croatia EC.

Comment: From the beginning of my interest for lichens, that’s about 10 years ago, I’ve been impressed by the beautiful picture of Teloschistes chrysophthalmus in the equally beautiful book Brodo, Sharnoff, S.Sharnoff (2001) Lichens of North America (Ref.2). The specimen pictured on book’s front cover seemed to me miraculous, from ‘tropical’ character and obviously rare. I have had little hope once to find it. Actually, Teloschistes chrysophthalmus is a widely scattered lichen present on north and south earth hemisphere (except in Asia and Antarctica) but in very localized areas and indeed rare at least in Europe. Literature states: “… very rare …” in England (Ref.:1), “… now (2005) probably already extinct from Britain…” (Ref.4): “… not documented from Check Republic…” (Ref.6), “…extremely rare…” in Italy (Ref.:9); “…extinct from Germany, Baden-Württemberg already at the beginning of 19. century…” (Ref.: 3). The species have been eliminated over many former places by habitat destruction and air pollution. But, on some places it is recently recolonizing its former distribution areas, like in south England (Ref.:12).

Presently there is no records of Teloschistes chrysophthalmus in the Boletus Informaticus Database for Slovenia (Ref.: 5). But, Ref.:11. states its presence in subalpine and Dinaric phytogeographical regions of the country. Records from Sub-Mediterranean region of Croatia along Adriatic Sea shore also exist (Ref. 8. – substratum Spartium junceus and Ref. 9. – substratum Quercus pubescens). However, a relatively recent lichen survey of the island Krk does not list this species (Ref.: 10). The closest find seems to be a single, more than hundred years old find in Kvarner bay littoral region next to the island Krk (Ref.:13). Eventually these pictures show the first documented observation of this species on the island Krk.

The find was, at the first moment, a small disappointment for me. Lichen tufts in dry state were quite inconspicuous, of muddy orange brown color and much, much smaller than their picture in my mind (based on Sharnoff’s beautiful macro picture). However, when looked through hand lens and in moist state they unfold their beauty incredibly. The bushy tufts were many, on many bushes along the narrow trail through macchia, altogether more than 100 individuals. They were mostly about 1 cm in diameter and 5-10 mm high, many were smaller and only some up to 2 cm across. All of them strictly inhabited small, dead or alive branches and twigs.

Camera: Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70 mm/f4

results.notes:
It is rare species among common X. poeltii. The size of talloms is 1×2mm up 5×6mm. They are thick and intergrowth with a poplar bark. Young tallom has short lobes (rarely branching) and pre-apothecia cylinders than small apothecia. Later apothecia covered tallom totally. Rhizins are absent. I have checked with a hand-lens about 300 trees in several locations for X. poeltii rhizins, but found only more kinds without rhizins.
C+ as pink vine, K+ deep purple up to dark reddish-brown.

results.notes:
It has combination of horizontal and vertical leafs. (Handbook of the Lichens of Russia, vol. 9, p. 263 has similar photo from Asia.) Apothecia size is 0.2-1.5mm. Apothecia are orange in dry season and dirty yellow or brownish-yellow in rainy time. Horizontal leafs are greenish-yellow and vertical leafs are yellow-orange on outer side with soredia. In rainy time leafs are more yellow with green spots. It is partially a free space between edges of some leafs and a bark, so rhizins are possible, but I have not found them in rainy time also.
C+ as pink vine, K+ deep purple up to dark reddish-brown.

results.notes:
The place is singular concerning the geology; it is one of the few basaltic outcrops in this region. In addition, the closer surrroundings are preserved in relation to the vegetation, consisting of native species, mainly oaks in the case of tees. The first observations from the place were taken on the local basaltic stones of a fence.
To start with I chose a species of Buellia, not yet identified, which is certainly new to me, with some pecularities: small thallus, very small apothecia and very small spores (when compared with the others in this genus). The photos obtained are not as good as they should be, because of the size and because of the damaged thalli. The same difficulty was present in the microscopy and I was not able to make a decent apothecial section.
Dimensions of the spores:
(6.9) 7.8 – 9.5 (11) × (4.7) 5 – 6.2 (6.8) µm
Q = (1.2) 1.3 – 1.7 (1.8) ; N = 32
Me = 8.4 × 5.5 µm ; Qe = 1.5

results.notes:
Growing on a mossy Thuja occidentalis log. Not releasing a latex when cut. Hyphae of the pileipellis with branched excrescences. Clamps present in the lamellar trama and the stipe trama. All lamellar structures inamyloid. Fusiod-ventricose to irregularly shaped, smooth cheilocystidia forming a sterile band on the gill edge. Some cheilocystidia with branched apices. Cheilocystidia measurements: (23.7) 27.4 – 37 (39.8) × (6.9) 6.95 – 9.1 (9.4) µm, Q = (2.9) 3 – 4.9 (5.3); N = 6, Me = 32.3 × 8.2 µm; Qe = 4. Pleurocystidia absent or rare. Caulocystidia similar to the cheilocystidia. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: 64.3 – 76.79 (76.8) × (15.5) 15.52 – 20 µm, Q = 3.2 – 4.76 (4.8); N = 5, Me = 72 × 17.6 µm; Qe = 4.1. Spores smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.2) 5.6 – 6.7 (7.5) × (4.5) 5 – 5.8 (6.4) µm, Q = 1 – 1.25 (1.3); N = 30, Me = 6.2 × 5.4 µm; Qe = 1.1

results.notes:
On calcareous shale in coastal scrub habitat.

Thallus a scant, thin, continuous tan crust. Apothecia erupting from thallus singly, then opening, becoming sessile, plane, with an epruinose dark maroon disk and raised margin generally with white thallus remnants clinging. Epihymenium orangish, hymenium and hypothecium hyaline. Exciple with dark margin. Paraphyses segmented, simple. Algae present at base of exciple.

Spores many per ascus, simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. 5.0×2.3 µm.

results.notes: Scattered on the edge of a pine thicket. Cap 3-6 cm wide, pale golden-yellow, fading upon maturity, darker colors on the disc and paler yellow (to nearly dirty white) near margin, with white(ish) volva remnants present (some falling/washing off) on the cap disc, margin tuberculate-striate (more so in age), veil remnants nearly absent to present (but scant/fragile) on cap margin. Gills white initially, though maturing/drying to a faint pale yellow/off-white coloration, some veil material present on the gills, several lengths of lamellulae present and generally truncate. Stipe about 0.75-1.25 cm thick and approx. 4-8 cm in length, whiteish, smooth to slightly pruinose near apex and the upper-mid portion, finely fibrillose towards with some off-white/yellowish coloration in the bottom half, bulbous base with some yellowish (veil?) material present and easily rubbed off. Spores subglobose to broadly elliptical, smooth and multigutulate (infrequently monogutulate), hyaline in KOH, ~ (9) 9.25 – 11.25 (11.8) x (6) 6.5 – 7.5 μm, (L’ = 10.25 μm; W’ = 6.98 μm; Q = 1.29- 1.62 μm; Q’ = 1.47 μm; N = 20); Basidia 4-sterigmata, clavate; no cystidia located on hymenium.

results.notes:
Growing on basaltic rock at Penedo de Lexim.
I wonder if this is Parmotrema pseudoreticulatum. According to the reference:
“Very close to Parmotrema reticulatum and recently separated from. Differs from Parmotrema reticulatum by its lobe variations, thicker, capitate apical soralia, sometimes laminal but only on erect lobes, by the absence of marginal cilia or if present, scarce and very short. Upper surface of lobes characterized by an incomplete reticulum, often limited to some macula towards the lobe base, but old lobes getting thicker may be more or less pleated.”

results.notes:
Of this collection, David Arora said: "The scaliness is weather-dependent. But there’s two easy ways to tell it from arvensis. First is the giant spores in crocodilinus (up to 14 um) scattered among smaller ones. They don’t even have to be measured to see that they are huge. After examining many collections here I stopped because every one was crocodilinus. I used to find arvensis a lot in Santa Cruz but it disappeared from that area in the early 1990s.

The second way is by the staining. In most collections of crocodilinus the flesh will stain orangish and then reddish at least when young in the stem. The process can take minutes or hours depending on temperature and moisture. I have never seen arvensis do that. The reddening is also mentioned in many European texts for macrosporus, a synonym of crocodilinus.

The first photo attached is of the mushrooms you sequenced. The red-staining was very slight. The second photo is from the same mycelium but a couple years ago during moist weather, and the staining was more obvious."

results.notes: Fruiting by Oak, flesh tough. Cap ~ 6-7 cm wide, slightly velvety, smooth, cuticle relatively adnate, hardly peeling. Gills aging to a slightly pale yellowish color (very pale), deposit pretty scant. Odor mild to somewhat pleasant, taste mild. Spores subglobose, though mostly broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid, with amyloid warts (mostly <0.25 μm) and mostly isolated, though some connections/ridges scattered, ~ 5.5 – 7 x (3.5) 4 – 5.8; cheilocystidia abundant, long with swollen bases and constricted apices, frequently exhibiting a knob, ~ 60 – 72 × 7.5 × 12.5; pleurocystidia similar to cheilocystidia, though not as abundant. Pileipellis a cutis with septate elements ranging 3 – 6 μm wide; caulocystidia present, long and cylindrical, narrowing at the apices, up to ~110 μm long with apices ~ 3 μm wide.

results.notes: Specimens were collected from a median in the middle of a roadway. The bark does not seem especially “fresh”, though the median looks like it is maintained with mulch annually. I suspect the mulch is chipping from a local arborist (mulch seems to be comprised predominantly of deciduous hard woods). The median is exposed and completely free of herbaceous plants and weeds. The largest planting on the median is a young small-medium sized western red cedar tree; it provides little to no canopy cover or shade. There are a handful of other coniferous sapling plantings dispersed sparsely along the length of the median; these saplings have little to no foliage and provide no shade from the sun. The fungi are fruiting prolifically in clusters along the entire median (median is approximately 200ft long by 15ft wide). The fungi do not seem to be concentrating around the bases of any specific trees. From what I can tell all of the fungi on the median seem to be the same species. Brown spore print.
